content: Het is inderdaad niet mogelijk Thunderbird nogmaals te starten als dezelfde processen nog actief zijn. Vraag is dus even waarom die processen blijven lopen na het afsluiten van Thunderbird. Loopt er bijvoorbeeld nog een synchronisatie van IMAP, of wordt Thunderbird te snel na afsluiten weer gestart? Overigens is er gisteren een nieuwe versie uit gekomen. Probeer eens bij te werken en kijk of het probleem er dan nog steeds is.
creator: Fjoerfoks

content:
I guess it happens because that is the certificate the server sends. Thunderbird thinks it is a bit odd that the server name does not match the certificate and asks you to verify that it is ok.

You could contact the people that administer the server and ask them why it is ending that certificate.

creator: jimhurley1

content: Ok, highlighting and pressing Delete key is probably not the solution you seek, so I presume there are many messages to keep, and others to delete. You could create a filter that selects a date range and set the action to move to trash. That would let you selectively empty from that time frame. Or am I still misunderstanding?
creator: davidsk

content: How do I do that. I see the Quick Filter box, or do I need to go somewhere else.
creator: jimhurley1

content: go to tools>message filters. There, create a filter for manual running that is always true, e.g. subject does not contain xxxxxx and an additional test for date prior to a specified date. For action, move to trash, NOT delete. Then, if you made a mistake, you can retrieve from trash. after creating filter, there will be an open row at bottom where you can specify a folder, such as inbox, and a button to run the filter.
creator: davidsk

content: Thunderbird didn't produce that popup, Google did. Google is asking your approval to authorize the use of the Thunderbird email client to be your agent in writing messages, reading messages and deleting messages. This is part of the Google security envelope. This is not a scam.

content:
That smells like an IMAP account problem. True? If so, that is indicative of an IMAP error. My suggestion is to delete the index for the folder and let Thunderbird rebuild it. To get to the file, try these steps: - click help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll down to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder' - exit thunderbird - click the imapmail folder and then the account folder. - you should now see the files, e.g., inbox, inbox.msf. - delete the .msf file - restart Thunderbird and I hope you get past the error.

- Now to fix the sink, locate the johnson rod attenuator support panel, recalibrate the automatic reversal pipe regenerative process, stand back three feet, count to ten, and voila!, the sink will be emptied.
creator: davidsk
